{{Politics of Puerto Rico}}
A '''constitutional referendum''' was held in [[Puerto Rico]] on 19 August 2012. Voters were asked whether they approve of two amendments to the [[Constitution of Puerto Rico|constitution]]; one to eliminate the absolute right to [[bail]] and the other to decrease the number of members of the [[Legislative Assembly of Puerto Rico|Legislative Assembly]].<ref>[http://www.ceepur.org/es-pr/Paginas/Referendum-2012.aspx Referendum 2012] CEEPUR</ref> Despite support from the party in government and part of the main opposition party, both amendments were rejected by voters.<ref name="virazon"/>
==Background== On January 9, 2012, Puerto Rican Governor [[Luis Fortuño]] signed the project for a Legislative Reform that would reduce the number of legislators. According to Fortuño, this would result in a decrease in the expenses associated with the operation of the Legislative Assembly. To achieve this, the constitution has to be amended, which would require a [[referendum]] to the people.<ref name="phreformaleg">{{cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/gobernadorconvierteenleyproyectodereformalegislativa-600506.html|title=Gobernador convierte en ley proyecto de Reforma Legislativa|work=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|author=|date=January 9, 2012}}</ref>
On May 10, 2012, the [[Senate of Puerto Rico|Senate]] approved a resolution that proposed another amendment to the Constitution, this time to eliminate the absolute right to [[bail]], specifically in murder cases, and others.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vocero.com/luz-verde-a-referendum-sobre-fianza/|title=Luz verde a referéndum sobre fianza|work=[[El Vocero]]|author=|date=May 11, 2012}}</ref> Governor Fortuño signed the resolution on May 15, agreeing to hold the referendum for both constitutional amendments on August 19, 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telemundopr.com/telenoticias/puerto-rico/Fortuno-firma-ley-de-referendum-para-limitar-la-fianza--151501755.html|title=Fortuño firma ley de referéndum para limitar la fianza|work=Telenoticias|author=Cyber News|date=May 15, 2012}}</ref>
Former Governors [[Rafael Hernández Colón]], [[Carlos Romero Barceló]], and [[Pedro Rosselló]], had tried unsuccessfully to eliminate the absolute right for [[bail]] during their tenures. Rosselló was the only one to hold a [[Puerto Rican constitutional referendum, 1994|referendum]] in 1994, but people voted against the amendment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.redbetances.com/component/content/article/51-en-portada/1122-perla-franco--claridad.html|title=Por cuarta ocasión, el gobierno quiere eliminar el derecho absoluto a la fianza|work=Red Betances|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
==Proposed amendments==
===Article III=== The first amendment applies to Article III, Sections 2, 3, 4, and 7. It proposes to reduce the members of the Legislative Assembly from 78 to 56. Specifically: *the number of [[Senate of Puerto Rico|senators]] would be reduced from 27 to 17 (11 district senators and 6 at-large)<ref name="phreformaleg"/> *the number of [[Puerto Rico House of Representatives|representatives]] would be reduced from 51 to 39 (33 district representatives and 6 at-large)<ref name="phreformaleg"/> This would require increasing the amount of [[Puerto Rico Senatorial districts|senatorial districts]] from 8 to 11, while reducing the [[Puerto Rico Representative districts|representative districts]] from 40 to 33.
===Article II=== The second amendment applies to Article II, Sections 11. It proposes to eliminate the absolute right to [[bail]], specifically in cases of those accused of: *[[premeditated murder]] *murder during a [[home invasion]] *murder during a kidnapping or sexual aggression *murder while shooting a firearm from a motor vehicle or in a public place *murdering a police officer while on duty In those cases, the judge will have the discretion of conceding or denying bail, after evaluating if the accused represents a risk to others or to the case.
==Voting process== Both proposed amendments were presented to the voters in a [[ballot]], with two questions. Each question asked if they approved the proposed amendment, to which the voters answered in a "Yes" or "No" checkbox to each question. Each ballot also presented the proposed amendment as it would have been featured in the [[Constitution of Puerto Rico]], if it had won.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ceepur.org/es-pr/Documents/ModeloRef12.pdf|title=Papeleta Modelo del Referendum 2012|publisher=CEEPUR|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
The ballot format was criticized by various groups, who considered it "difficult to read", according to José Acarón, state director of the [[AARP]]. Roberto Aponte, electoral commissioner for the [[Puerto Rican Independence Party]] (PIP) also stated that the ballot would be "troublesome to read". Ramón Jiménez, director of the referendum scrutiny, assured that the ballot was readable, but also said that voting colleges would have enlarged ballots for anyone who needed them.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/laspapeletasdelreferendumsondedificillectura-1319398.html|title=Las papeletas del referéndum son de difícil lectura|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Santiago, Yaritza|date=August 10, 2012}}</ref>
Prisons in Puerto Rico held the voting process for the referendum on August 17, 2012 with approximately 8,350 of 11,800 prisoners participating. Former [[Speaker of the House of Representatives of Puerto Rico|Speaker]] of the [[Puerto Rican House of Representatives]] and convict [[Edison Misla Aldarondo]] voted in a Bayamón prison. He said to a newspaper that he voted in favor of eliminating the absolute right for [[bail]] because "it is a mechanism to deal with the crime situation." However, he voted against the proposed Legislative Reform saying that "quality and quantity are two different things".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/convictoexpresidentedelacamaravotosiparalimitarlafianza-1324773.html|title=Convicto expresidente de la Cámara voto "Si" para limitar la fianza|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Santiago, Yaritza|date=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
On August 19, 2012, 3,151 voting colleges opened at 8:00am and closed at 3:00pm.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.analitica.com/va/sintesis/internacionales/7148451.asp|title=Comienza jornada para referendo de enmienda constitucional|work=Analítica|author=|date=August 19, 2012}}</ref>
==Campaign==
===Opponents=== Reaction to the proposed amendments was mixed, with several groups deciding to campaign against them answering "No" to each question.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telemundopr.com/telenoticias/puerto-rico/Frente-comun-contra-el-Referendum-del-19-de-agosto-165576996.html|title=Frente común contra el referéndum del 19 de agosto|work=Telemundo|date=August 9, 2012}}</ref> A coalition group called ''Frente Amplio de Puerto Rico: Mesa Amplia de Diálogo'' decided to campaign against both amendments and declared August 17, 2012 to be the "Day of No and No". The group is formed by new parties [[Movimiento Unión Soberanista]] (MUS), [[Puerto Ricans for Puerto Rico Party]] (PPR), and the [[Worker's People Party of Puerto Rico]] (PPT), along with groups like the Alianza Pro Libre Asociación Soberana (ALAS), Church's Council, and the Ecumenic Coalition.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/campanamasivaafavordevotarnoenelreferendum-1323882.html|title=Campaña masiva a favor de votar "No" en el referéndum|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Rivera, Ivelisse|date=August 16, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/seunenvariospartidosparafavorecerelnoenelreferendum-681571.html|title=Se unen varios partidos para favorecer el "No" en el referéndum|work=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|author=Cordero, Gerardo|date=August 9, 2012}}</ref>
The [[Puerto Rican Independence Party]] (PIP) is campaigning against both amendments, arguing that the proposed Legislative Reform would "crush minorities" by increasing the amount of votes that minority candidates would need to be elected. Several weeks before the referendum, they also argued that there was still confusion among the voters, and that electoral participation will be around 20%.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/pipiolossepreparanparaelreferendum-1316260.html|title=Pipiolos se preparan para el referéndum|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Banuchi, Rebecca|date=August 5, 2012}}</ref>
Héctor Pesquera, co-president of the [[Hostosian National Independence Movement]] (MINH) asked people to vote against the amendments arguing that eliminating the absolute right to [[bail]] won't be a solution to the rising [[crime rate]] in the island.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/ignoranciaciudadanavenceriaenelreferendum-1321225.html|title=Ignorancia ciudadana vencería en el referéndum|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=|date=August 12, 2012}}</ref> The members of the [[Ateneo Puertorriqueño]], one of the main cultural institutions of the island, also wrote a statement against the amendments calling them an "attempt on people's rights".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://redbetances.com/comunicados/53-comunicados-de-prensa/1143-ateneo-puertorriqueno.html|title=Ateneo Puertorriqueño insta a votar "No" en el referéndum|publisher=Red Betances|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
Various leaders within the [[Popular Democratic Party of Puerto Rico|Popular Democratic Party]] (PPD) campaigned against the amendments. Former Governor [[Aníbal Acevedo Vilá]] posted a video on his [[blog]] in which he asked people to vote "No".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/acevedovilacompartevideoafavordelnoenelreferendum-1313895.html|title=Acevedo Vilá comparte video a favor del "No" en el referéndum|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=|date=August 2, 2012}}</ref> The former President of the Senate, [[Miguel Hernández Agosto]], and former gubernatorial candidate, [[Victoria Muñoz Mendoza]], also stated their opposition to the amendments.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/hernandezagostoestaencontradelimitarelderechoalafianza-683314.html|title=Hernández Agosto está en contra de limitar el derecho a la fianza|work=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|author=Peña, Brenda|date=August 15, 2012}}</ref><ref name="ppddividido">{{cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/lafianzadividealppdyagarciapadilla-647568.html|title=La fianza divide al PPD y a Padilla|work=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|author=Díaz, Maritza and Nydia Bauzá|date=May 16, 2012}}</ref> Current candidates [[Rafael Cox Alomar]], [[Eduardo Bhatia]] and [[Carmen Yulín Cruz]] also said they were against the amendments, despite the position of the president of the party and current gubernatorial candidate [[Alejandro García Padilla]] to vote in favor.<ref name="ppddividido"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wapa.tv/noticias/politica/cox-alomar-se-va-en-contra-de-garcia-padilla_20120516080829.html|title=Cox Alomar se va en contra de García Padilla|work=[[WAPA-TV]]|author=|date=May 16, 2012}}</ref>
Human rights activist [[Pedro Julio Serrano]] expressed himself against the amendments, arguing that the problem wasn't the [[bail]], but rather that "7 out of 10 cases are solved". He also offered statistics from the Legal Assistance Association that showed that, out of 100 persons accused of murder during a year, only eight received the benefit of freedom while awaiting their trial.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/portavozdeorganizacionpuertoricoparatod@spidevotarno-1324838.html|title=Portavoz de organización Puerto Rico Para Tod@s pide votar "No"|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Inter News|date=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
The Puerto Rico Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers (PRACDL) also expressed themselves against the amendments. In their statement, they argued that "preventive detention hasn't contributed to make Puerto Rico, or United States, a safer place for their citizens, nor does it contribute to a culture of respect to the rights of others."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telemundopr.com/telenoticias/voto-2012/Abogados-federales-en-contra-de-la-limitacion-a-la-fianza-166235516.html|title=Abogados federales en contra de la limitación a la fianza|work=Telenoticias|author=|date=August 15, 2012}}</ref>
On August 2012, Puerto Rican singer/actor [[Ricky Martin]] posted on his website "To amend the Constitution goes beyond party ideologies. Don't let fear and frustration decide your vote. The rights we already have shouldn't be relinquished."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/rickymartinapoyaelnoenelreferendum-683304.html|title=Ricky Martin apoya el "No" en el referéndum|work=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|author=|date=August 15, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/rickymartinvaporelnoenlaconsultadeestedomingo-1323238.html|title=Ricky Martin va por el "No" en la consulta de este domingo|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=|date=August 15, 2012}}</ref> René Pérez, from [[Calle 13 (band)|Calle 13]], also invited people to vote "No" to the amendments. Pérez wrote on his [[Facebook]] page "You wouldn't amputate an arm or a leg, unless it was to save your life. The same happens with freedom. The right for bail is part of it. You shouldn't vote to have a part of you amputated. Think. If one day you're wrongly accused, you should have the right to be free while you wait to prove it" and added "Limit the weapons, not our rights."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/reneperezreiterasuapoyoalnoenelreferendum-683887.html|title=René Pérez reitera su apoyo al "No" en el referéndum|work=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|author=|date=August 16, 2012}}</ref>
A group of artists under the name of ''Artistas en Defensa al Derecho a la Fianza'' also made statements against the proposed amendments to the Constitution. The group, led by actor Luis Enrique Romero, included artists from several branches like actresses Ineabelle Colón, Amneris Morales, Magali Carrasquillo, and Anamín Santiago; folk singers José Antonio "Tony Mapeyé" Rivera and Eduardo Villanueva; singers/musicians [[Haciendo Punto en Otro Son|Irvin García]] and Pepe Sánchez; painter Pablo Marcano, and photographer Félix Guayciba. During a press conference, actress Amneris Morales called the current government "a dictatorship", while fellow actress Carrasquillo argued that "not everybody will be accused with the same severity".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/artistasdicennoynoalreferendum-684499.html|title=Artistas dicen No y No al referéndum|work=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|author=Marrero, Rosalina|date=August 18, 2012}}</ref>
The parents of Karla Michelle Negrón, a 15-year-old girl that was killed by a [[Celebratory gunfire|stray bullet]] during [[New Year's Eve]], said they would vote against the amendments, stating that it "simplifies a bigger problem" and that it "won't help fight against crime".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telemundopr.com/telenoticias/ultimas-noticias/Papa-de-Karla-Michelle-votara-no-a-la-limitacion-de-fianza-165474276.html|title=Papá de Karla Michelle votará "no" a la limitación de fianza|work=Telenoticias|author=|date=August 8, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/videos-politica-padresdekarlamichelleencontradelreferendum-1789693257001.html|title=Padres de Karla Michelle en contra del referendum|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
===Proponents===
Governor [[Luis Fortuño]] and his party, [[New Progressive Party of Puerto Rico|New Progressive Party]] (PNP), campaigned in favor of the proposed amendments. Most of the leaders of the party support him and will campaign with him.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telemundopr.com/telenoticias/puerto-rico/PNP-lanza-segunda-fase-de-la-campana-a-favor-del-SI--165400416.html|title=PNP lanza segunda fase de la campaña a favor del "Si"|work=Telenoticias|author=Cyber News|date=August 8, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vocero.com/fortuno-lidera-caravana-a-favor-del-si-en-el-referendum/|title=Fortuño lidera caravana a favor del "Si" en el referéndum|work=[[El Vocero]]|author=Torres, Raúl|date=August 4, 2012}}</ref> [[Thomas Rivera Schatz]], President of the [[Senate of Puerto Rico]], asked voters to participate of the referendum and encouraged them to vote in favor of the amendments.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/riveraschatzpideaelectoresquesalganavotarenelreferendum-682616.html|title=Rivera Schatz pide a electores que salgan a votar en el referéndum|work=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|author=|date=August 12, 2012}}</ref> Also, a group of chiefs of agencies made statements in favor of the amendments. The group, led by Chief of Staff [[Miguel Romero]], included [[Guillermo Somoza]] (Justice), Yanitzia Irizarry (Family), Miguel Hernández Vivoni (Housing), [[Jesús F. Méndez]] ([[Puerto Rico Treasury Department|Treasury]]), [[Henry Neumann]] ([[Puerto Rico Department of Sports and Recreation|Sports and Recreation]]), and Jesús González (Correction).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/jefesdeagenciaexhortanavotarafavordelaenmiendaalafianza-1324833.html|title=Jefes de agencia exhortan a votar a favor de la enmienda a la fianza|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Muñíz, Alba Y.|date=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
[[Alejandro García Padilla]], current senator and gubernatorial candidate for the opposing [[Popular Democratic Party of Puerto Rico|Popular Democratic Party]] (PPD), also expressed he would vote in favor of the amendments. His posture came as a surprise, since he voted against the resolution in the [[Senate of Puerto Rico]]. He said that "with the referendum already approved and in the absence of other legislative mechanisms like the ones we have proposed during this term to fight against crime, I express myself in favor of this amendment and I will vote accordingly."<ref name="virazonagp">{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/virazondegarciapadillaenlaconsultadelafianza-1256902.html|title=Virazón de García Padilla en la consulta de la fianza|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Alvarado, Gerardo|date=August 15, 2012}}</ref> Former governors [[Sila María Calderón]] and [[Rafael Hernández Colón]] expressed themselves in favor of the amendments, along with other members of the party like [[Sila María González Calderón]],<ref name="virazonagp"/> [[Luis Raúl Torres Cruz]], [[Jorge Colberg Toro]], and others.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/grupodepopularesanuncianapoyoalsienelreferendum-1314784.html|title=Grupo de populares anuncian apoyo al "Si" en el referéndum|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=|date=August 3, 2012}}</ref>
A group of judges, including Efraín Rivera Pérez, a former judge of the [[Supreme Court of Puerto Rico]], and Héctor Laffitte, former federal judge, expressed themselves in favor of the amendments.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/videos-noticias-juecesafavordelsienelreferendum-1785611434001.html|title=Jueces a favor del "Si" en el referéndum|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=|accessdate=August 17, 2012}}</ref> Also, former two-time Superintendent of the [[Puerto Rico Police Department]], [[Pedro Toledo]], expressed himself in favor of the amendments. He added that some guidelines could be needed to allow judges to define the issue of the dangerousness of the accused.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wapa.tv/noticias/locales/exjueces-a-favor-del-si_20120814144849.html|title=Exjueces a favor del "Si"|work=[[WAPA-TV]]|author=Cyber News|date=August 14, 2012}}</ref>
Astrologer [[Walter Mercado]] said on a statement that he favored both amendments to the Constitution. He wrote that he considered the amendment on the right to bail to be an important tool on the fight against crime, and that it was "a step ahead in the control of the rising crime rate." He added that the amendment would "protect good and decent people from criminals that used their time on bail to threaten witnesses and commit more crimes."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/waltermercadofavoreceelsi-1324896.html|title=Walter Mercado favorece el "Si"|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=|date=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
===Advertisements=== The [[New Progressive Party of Puerto Rico|New Progressive Party]] (PNP) published advertisements in favor of the amendments using the pictures of two young men recently accused of murder. The pictures, taken after their arrests, show both men with their [[Finger (gesture)|middle fingers]] to the camera. The advertisement reads "If you don't vote, they win". The mother of one of the men in the picture, Vilmarie Carrasquillo, presented a preliminary [[injunction]] to withdraw the advertisement, arguing that his son's right for privacy was violated. However, the San Juan Court determined that the PNP could continue using the advertisement.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/pnppodraseguirconanuncioquetienefotosdejovenesacusados-679656.html|title=PNP podrá seguir con anuncio que tiene fotos de jóvenes acusados|work=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|author=Cobián, Mariana|date=August 3, 2012}}</ref> Two days before the referendum, the Supreme Court ratified the decision of the Court of San Juan allowing the PNP to continue with their campaign.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/supremodeclaranohalugarpeticionparareconsiderarretiraranunciopnp-1324889.html|title=Supremo declara no ha lugar petición para reconsiderar retirar anuncio PNP|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Cobián, Mariana|date=August 17, 2012}}</ref>
==Opinion polls== A poll by local newspaper ''[[El Nuevo Día]]'' was published on August 12, 2012. The poll had the following results:<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/resultadosdeencuestadanlarazonagarciapadilla-1321157.html|title=Resultados de la encuesta dan la razón a García Padilla|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=|date=August 12, 2012}}</ref> * 59% support the elimination of the absolute right for [[bail]], against a 27% opposition. 14% was still undecided. * 76% support the decrease in the amount of legislators, against a 13% opposition. 11% was still undecided.
The poll, which was designed and analyzed by Kaagan Research Associates, included a [[sampling (statistics)|sample]] of 1,000 people and could produce an error of ±3%.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/comosellevoacabolaencuestadeelnuevodia-1323276.html|title=Cómo se llevó a cabo la encuesta de El Nuevo Día|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=|date=August 16, 2012}}</ref>
==Results== The first preliminary results were announced by the [[State Elections Commission of Puerto Rico]] at around 4:00.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/ceeemiteprimerosresultadosdelreferendum-1325971.html|title=CEE emite primeros resultados del referéndum|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Resto, Mara and Gerardo Cordero|date=August 19, 2012}}</ref> At around 6:25pm, Luis Fortuño's campaign director Angel Cintrón announced that there was a tendency against the amendments in the results so far. During a press conference, he said "It's not what we expected, it's different to our projections, and we have to accept it." However, he added that the results weren't definitive yet since there were still more than 50% of votes to count.<ref name="virazon">{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/virazondavictoriaalno-1326035.html|title=Virazón da la victoria al "No"|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Rodríguez, Israel|date=August 19, 2012}}</ref> [[Thomas Rivera Schatz]], President of the [[Senate of Puerto Rico]], also acknowledged the defeat saying that the amendments his party had proposed "weren't accepted and that people don't want to amend the Constitution". He added that there could have been some misinformation in the process.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/riveraschatzreconoceeltriunfodelno-1326081.html|title=Rivera Schatz reconoce el triunfo del "No"|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=Ruíz, Gloria|date=August 19, 2012}}</ref> The results on the absolute bail bill means that "Puerto Rico remains the only place in the Western Hemisphere where everyone is entitled to bail regardless of the alleged crime."<ref>[http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/puerto-ricans-vote-constitutional-amendments-17036826 ''Puerto Ricans Reject Constitutional Amendments.''] Danica Coto (Associated Press). 19 August 2012 ABC News. Retrieved 20 August 2012.</ref>
The final results, according to the [[State Elections Commission of Puerto Rico]], were:<ref>[http://64.185.222.182/REFERENDUM_REFORMA_LEGISLATIVA_Y_ENMIENDA_SOBRE_LA_FIANZA_46/NOCHE_DEL_EVENTO_68/default.html Resultados Referendum 2012] on CEEPUR</ref>
{{Referendum | title = Eliminate the right for absolute bail | yes = 364,169 | yespct = 44.82 | no = 448,272 | nopct = 55.18 | valid = 812,441 | validpct = 99.22 | invalid = 6,371 | invalidpct = 0.78 | total = 818,812 | turnoutpct = 35.50 | electorate = 2,306,769 | source = [http://64.185.222.182/REFERENDUM_REFORMA_LEGISLATIVA_Y_ENMIENDA_SOBRE_LA_FIANZA_46/ESCRUTINIO_69/default.html CEE] }}{{Referendum | title = Change the amount of legislators | yes = 371,042 | yespct = 45.72 | no = 440,453 | nopct = 54.28 | valid = 811,495 | validpct = 99.10 | invalid = 7,409 | invalidpct = 0.90 | total = 818,904 | turnoutpct = 35.50 | electorate = 2,306,769 | source = [http://64.185.222.182/REFERENDUM_REFORMA_LEGISLATIVA_Y_ENMIENDA_SOBRE_LA_FIANZA_46/ESCRUTINIO_69/default.html CEE] }}
==Aftermath== At 7:00pm, Governor [[Luis Fortuño]] held a press conference, along with [[Pedro Pierluisi]], where he conceded the defeat of the "Yes" camp. In his message, he said that "this isn't about one party or one government" and assured those that supported him that they would keep on working "outside of party lines, so that everyone can be part of the solution".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/fortunoaceptaqueelsifuederrotado-1326093.html|title=Fortuño acepta que el "Si" fue derrotado|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=|date=August 19, 2012}}</ref> On the other hand, Senator and [[Popular Democratic Party of Puerto Rico|PPD]] gubernatorial candidate [[Alejandro García Padilla]] blamed Fortuño and Pierluisi for the loss during a press conference.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elnuevodia.com/garciapadilladicequefueunvotodenocontrafortunoypierluisi-1326085.html|title=García Padilla dice que fue un voto de "No" contra Fortuño y Pierluisi|work=[[El Nuevo Día]]|author=|date=August 19, 2012}}</ref>
At the [[Puerto Rico Bar Association]], groups that were against the amendments started celebrating the preliminary results.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/celebrantriunfodelnoenelcolegiodeabogados-684932.html|title=Celebran triunfo del "No" en el Colegio de Abogados|work=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|author=Díaz, Maritza|date=August 19, 2012}}</ref> Former Governor [[Aníbal Acevedo Vilá]] celebrated the victory saying that "reason triumphed over fear and money".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.primerahora.com/anibalacevedoviladicequetriunfolarazonlaverdadyelamor-684928.html|title=Anibal Acevedo Vila dice que triunfo larazón, la verdad y el amor|work=''[[Primera Hora (Puerto Rico)|Primera Hora]]''|author=|date=August 19, 2012}}</ref> The [[Puerto Rican Independence Party|PIP]] gubernatorial candidate [[Juan Dalmau Ramírez]] said that the defeat represented a "moral defeat" for both Fortuño and García Padilla.<ref name="virazon"/>
